central_thesis: This book presents a meticulously transcribed and annotated 17th-century grimoire (Ms. Harley 6482), attributed to Dr. Thomas Rudd, outlining a comprehensive Hermetic-Qabalistic system for the theurgic invocation and visible manifestation of angels from various hierarchies for spiritual development, wisdom, and practical magical operations.

structure_content.summary: McLean contextualizes the manuscript, situating 'A Treatise on Angel Magic' within the broader lineage of Western Esotericism, highlighting its connections to John Dee, the Rosicrucian tradition, and earlier Solomonic grimoires, emphasizing its significance as a detailed source for 17th-century angelic magic.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Ten Names of God, with their Ideas, Orbs, and Hierarchies Largely Explained
structure_content.summary: This section lays the Qabalistic and cosmological foundation of the system, detailing the ten Divine Names, their emanations, the corresponding angelic hierarchies (e.g., Seraphim, Cherubim, Thrones), and their attributions to celestial orbs, providing the essential framework for understanding angelic authority and function.

The 'Key of the Holy Table' details the construction and significance of the central magical altar for angelic operations. It provides a foundational diagram, explaining the arrangement of divine and angelic names, seals, and geomantic figures required to establish the consecrated ritual space.

This part presents intricate magical squares and their associated intelligences and demons for each of the seven traditional planets (Luna, Mercurii, Veneris, Solis, Martis, Iovis, Saturni). These tables are fundamental for aligning operations with specific planetary energies and invoking their corresponding entities.

This chapter enumerates and describes the 72 Angels derived from the Shemhamphorash, providing specific invocations or divine epithets for each, enabling practitioners to call upon these angels for targeted assistance in various spiritual and material affairs.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Names of Some of the Good and Bad Spirits Solomon Made Use of
structure_content.summary: An extensive catalog of spirits, both benevolent and malevolent, detailing their forms, offices, and powers. This serves as a practical directory for identifying and understanding the entities that may be invoked or encountered in magical operations, including their governance and specific attributes.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Alphabet of Angels and Genii, or the Writing and Language of Heaven
structure_content.summary: This section introduces a celestial alphabet and provides guidelines for its use in magical inscriptions. This script is crucial for crafting talismans, seals, and other ritualistic items, imbuing them with divine and angelic power through their written representation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Of the Little Tables of the Planets
structure_content.summary: This offers supplementary planetary tables, including divine names, angelic intelligences, associated demons, and sigils. These tables provide practical tools for designing and charging talismans and other magical implements with specific planetary and angelic influences.

structure_content.chapter_title: DR. RUDD'S NINE HIERARCHIES OF ANGELS WITH THEIR INVOCATIONS TO VISIBLE APPEARANCE
structure_content.summary: This pivotal section, constituting the core of Rudd's system, presents the explicit methods and procedures for invoking the nine angelic hierarchies to achieve their visible manifestation and direct communication with the operator.

Provides detailed practical instructions and protocols for conducting angelic invocations. It covers essential aspects such as preparing the operator, setting up the space, discerning the appearance and nature of manifested spirits (both good and evil), engaging in communication, and proper dismissal.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Nine Great Celestial Keys or Angelical Invocations
structure_content.summary: Outlines nine specific, elaborate invocations, each corresponding to an angelic hierarchy and its associated celestial sphere. These 'Keys' are complex prayers, incorporating Divine Names and angelic epithets, designed to compel and draw forth angels for visible manifestation and communication.

This section illustrates and explains the magical seals associated with major planetary angels (e.g., Metratton, Raziel, Cassiel, Sachiel, Samael, Michael, Anael, Raphael, Gabriel). These seals are critical ritualistic elements, used for invocation, protection, and as focal points of angelic energy.

Introduces and describes the seven Olympian spirits (Aratron, Bethor, Phaleg, Och, Hagith, Ophiel, Phul), detailing their respective domains, forms, and powers. This section expands the repertoire of entities available for invocation, often for specific, practical worldly effects.

key_concepts.definition: A comprehensive ceremonial magic system focused on the theurgic invocation of celestial beings (angels) to visible appearance for divine wisdom, assistance, and manifestation of desires, rooted in Hermetic-Qabalistic cosmology and characterized by meticulous ritual preparation.

Hebrew names of God (e.g., Eheia, Iod Hevova, Elohim Gibor) used as powerful linguistic keys to access and direct divine energy, activate specific Qabalistic spheres, and invoke corresponding angelic hierarchies or entities.

A structured celestial order, typically involving nine ranks (e.g., Seraphim, Cherubim, Thrones, Dominions), each associated with a Divine Name, planetary sphere, and specific angelic intelligences, forming the 'chain of being' through which divine influence descends.

A consecrated ritualistic table, often inscribed with divine and angelic names, planetary seals, and geomantic figures, serving as the central altar, energetic nexus, and manifestation platform for angelic invocations.

The 72 Angels derived from the 72-fold Name of God (based on Exodus 14:19-21), each possessing distinct powers and offices, frequently invoked for specific magical operations, protection, or spiritual guidance.

The practice of using a consecrated crystal, mirror (shewstone), or other reflective surface as a medium or 'gateway' for facilitating the visible appearance, auditory communication, and intelligible interaction with invoked angels or spirits.

A system integrating angels, intelligences, and spirits associated with the seven traditional planets. It utilizes specific planetary hours, days, seals, and tables to align magical operations with particular celestial influences for targeted effects.

Consecrated magical objects or images, often inscribed with angelic names, seals, planetary symbols, and celestial alphabets, crafted to draw down and embody specific planetary or angelic influences for a desired magical effect or protective purpose.

The practical guidelines and instructions provided for the operative magician, covering detailed procedures for effective invocation, managing visible manifestations of spirits, discerning their nature (good or evil), proper communication protocols, and formal banishing.

Elaborate prayers or formulae, often complex and incorporating Divine Names, angelic names, and Qabalistic references, meticulously designed to compel and draw forth angels to visible manifestation and direct communication with the magician.

practical_system.description: The system described in 'A Treatise on Angel Magic' is a comprehensive, theurgic system for invoking angels and other spirits to visible appearance and direct communication. It is highly ceremonial, rooted in a Christianized Qabalistic-Hermetic cosmology that emphasizes purity, divine authority, and the meticulous preparation of the operator, ritual space, and magical tools. The magic operates by aligning the microcosm (magician) with the macrocosm (divine and angelic hierarchies) through the precise use of divine names, angelic seals, planetary correspondences, and specific invocations to channel celestial influences for wisdom, guidance, or manifestation of desires.
tools: Holy Table (Tabula Sancta): The primary consecrated altar, intricately designed with divine and angelic names and symbols.
Shewstone/Crystal or Magical Mirror: The scrying medium for visible manifestation and communication with spirits.
Lamen: A consecrated breastplate worn by the operator, bearing divine names and seals for authority, protection, and as a symbol of priestly office.
Magical Rod or Wand: Used for commanding, directing energy, and marking the magical circle.
Seals and Sigils: Specific geometric or symbolic representations of angels, planetary intelligences, and other spirits, used in invocations and talisman construction.
Talismans (Telesmes): Consecrated objects crafted to embody and project specific celestial or angelic influences.
Book of Conjurations: The grimoire itself, containing the invocations, names, seals, and operational instructions.
Protective Circle of Art: A ritually defined sacred space for the magician's safety and containment of invoked entities (implied by tradition, though not always fully detailed in this text).
Purification Implements: Incense, consecrated water, and anointing oils for cleansing and blessing.
rituals: Purification and Consecration: The operator undergoes spiritual and physical purification (e.g., fasting, prayer) and consecrates all ritual tools and the workspace.

Construction of the Holy Table (Tabula Sancta): A central magical altar is created and inscribed with specific Divine Names, angelic seals, and geomantic figures as detailed in the 'Clavis Tabulae Sanctae', serving as the nexus of the operation.

Invocation through Celestial Keys: The operator recites the 'Nine Great Celestial Keys,' elaborate prayers and formulae that specifically address angelic hierarchies by their Divine Names, compelling them to manifest.

Skrying and Manifestation: A consecrated shewstone (crystal or mirror) is used as the medium through which angels are expected to appear visibly and communicate intelligibly. The 'Directory' guides the magician on discerning manifestations and interaction.

Planetary and Shemhamphorash Operations: Invocations and talismanic workings are tailored to specific planetary hours and days, or directed towards particular Shemhamphorash angels or other listed spirits for targeted magical effects.
Communication and Instruction: Once manifested, angels are questioned for divine wisdom, spiritual guidance, or to perform specific tasks, always under the authority of the Highest Divine Names.
Banishing and Dismissal: Strict protocols are followed for courteously dismissing the invoked entities and formally closing the ritual, ensuring no lingering unwanted influences remain.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is exceptionally relevant as a foundational text in the Western Esoteric Tradition, bridging early Solomonic grimoires with later ceremonial magic systems. It provides invaluable insight into 17th-century Hermetic and Rosicrucian thought, serving as a primary source for understanding the development of angelic magic. Its detailed system, combining Qabalistic theory with practical invocation, offers a comprehensive framework for students and practitioners of theurgy. It also illuminates the historical context and potential influences on later traditions, such as the Golden Dawn, through its emphasis on hierarchical invocation, divine names, and specific ritual tools.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes academic scholars of esotericism, occult history, and religious studies, as well as experienced practitioners of ceremonial magic, Hermeticism, and theurgy. Individuals seeking to reconstruct or understand historical grimoire traditions, particularly those focused on angelic communication and visible manifestation, will find this text indispensable. It is not intended for beginners due to the complexity of its system and the inherent dangers associated with such operations without proper theoretical grounding and practical experience.
